content.desc: Bom dia Portugal! We’re meeting some great people here in Lisbon. Portugal Telecom, EDP, CGD and ZON so far.
We’ve taken our 16.5m truck about as far as we can in this direction. Lisbon is the westernmost capital city in Europe.
Wow! More than 2,000km in three days. From ice caps in Switzerland to ice-creams in Lisbon – this is one cool truck.
The Spanish traditionally enjoy a siesta in the middle of the day, but there’s no rest for us. On and up to Madrid, 635m above sea level
It’s great to be in Spain, where we’ll be seeing SAP customers Amadeus, Telefonica, Enel, Revlon, Cirsa and Gas Natural.
I left the truck for a quick fly around FC Barcelona’s Camp Nou stadium. It’s the largest in Europe, with a capacity of 99,354.
Every day around 24 million journeys are made on the London transport system. That must generate an awful lot of data.
At the Farnborough Air Show, where we’re explaining how SAP HANA can enable predictive maintenance that keeps planes flying.
We’re visiting Yorkshire Water, which owns 28,000 hectares of Yorkshire, including 17 nature reserves. My kind of company.
The truck weighs 33 tonnes, but it handled well as we drove through the Pyrenees from Barcelona to Pau. Beautiful views too.
Visiting Lille in northern France, which has around 200 mail-order businesses and 10 business schools. Sounds perfect for a Big Data session.
Luckily the hunting season in France doesn’t start until September. I think it’s safe for owls until then!
We’re rolling along the roads of Belgium, home to the EU, NATO and about 11 million people.
Belgium has no fewer than three official languages: Dutch, French and German – wonder if Big Data is the same in all three?
We’ve just driven past a lovely bird sanctuary near Knokke in Belgium. I think I spotted some old friends flying around
We’re off to SAP’s Netherlands HQ in Den Bosch for Big Data Inspiration Day. Speakers from SAP, Cap Gemini, IDC and Alliander.
Vodafone Netherlands were telling us how they use SAP Big Data technology to keep customers happy and reduce churn.
I’ve been trying out the local traditions here in the Netherlands, but it’s hard to fly when you’re wearing clogs.
We’re visiting the International Telecommunications Union in Geneva, birthplace of the World Wide Web.
From the streets of Geneva to the country lanes of Mex, where we visit Bobst, an SAP customer that supplies packaging equipment to the world
I think the best thing about Switzerland is their amazing chocolate. They’ve been making it here since the 17th century.
We’re off to Milan, just in time for Fashion Week. Clothing retailers are already using Big Data to predict new trends.
We’ve met lovely people at Saipem today. They’re big players in the energy industry, marrying technology with sustainability.
Like lots of other birds, I’m heading south. I bet they’re not going to Italy though. Where are my trendy sunglasses?
Our first stop in Denmark is Ecco, famous for its shoes. It manages every stage of production, from tannery to retail.
The truck feels like new after our holiday. Good job, as we’ve got thousands of kilometers to travel in the next few weeks.
We’re back on the road after two weeks for rest and repairs. Welcome to Denmark – now where’s that pastry?
We’re in the northernmost country of our tour. Norway also has the world’s largest sovereign wealth fund, at over $830 billion.
Norway has 393km of motorways, but only one heliport. Good job we’re travelling by truck, not helicopter.
13 types of owl have been recorded in Norway, including the Eurasian Pygmy Owl. It’s nice to be among family again.
Three big Swedish companies in one day: Mölnlycke, Volvo and SKF. It’s amazing what Big Data can do in almost every industry.
Sweden has always been famous for technical innovations, so it’s the perfect place to be talking about Big Data and SAP HANA.
Stockholm looks amazing from the air. It’s built on 14 distinct islands. 30% of the city is waterways and another 30% green spaces.
Our grand tour starts at SAP headquarters in Walldorf, Germany, which cover a total of 19.91km<sup>2</sup>.
We stop in Bonn to visit DPDHL, which has around 480,000 employees in 220 countries.
So far on the tour I’ve eaten salad in Walldorf and sausages in Frankfurt. I think a theme is developing. Are we going to Hamburg?
Next stop, Vienna, which will host this year’s SAP MaxAttention summit from 26-28 October.
We’re driving on the excellent autobahns of Austria, which have a speed limit, unlike the German versions.
Austria will host the Eurovision Song Contest next year. Do you think I’ve got a chance of winning? Too-wit too-woo!
The Czech people are rightly proud of their scientific heritage, including Gregor Mendel, the ‘father of genetics’.
Prague is the sixth most visited city in Europe. Shame we missed the beer festival, which is held in May and lasts 17 days.
If you meet my cousin the Eurasian Eagle-Owl here in the Czech Republic, don’t call him by his Latin name – Bubo bubo. He hates it.
It’s exciting to be here in Slovakia, which has one of the fastest growth rates in Europe. It joined the EU in 2004.
Car manufacturing and electrical engineering are major industries in Slovakia. And they’re both big users of Big Data.
Andy Warhol’s parents were from Slovakia and ice hockey is the most popular sport here. I don’t think he played it though.
Many multinational companies have set up R&D centres here in Poland. It’s the biggest R&D hub in central and eastern Europe.
Telecoms company TPSA Poland used Big Data analytics to improve the accuracy of its churn model by 50%.
Poland has 14 sites inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage, including historic cities and royal salt mines.
Next stops are Finland’s two largest cities: Helsinki and Espoo. Technology centres with thriving universities and lots of start-ups.
Finland is the last Nordic country on our schedule before we head south. We’ll miss all these lovely people.
I love the meatballs they make here in Finland. They’re called lihapullat and you eat them with gravy and lingonberry jam. Delicious.
